newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Socialists against EU Commission censure on BSE.
newsitem.headline: Socialists against EU Commission censure on BSE.

text.p: The largest group in the European Parliament on Friday dismissed as "ill-judged" a move by some Euro-MPs to throw the European Commission out of office next week because of its handling of the mad cow crisis.

A statement from the parliament's Socialist Group described a pending censure motion against the EU executive as a "fringe attempt" that would, if successful, put the European Union into a crisis that would serve no one.
"The top priority is protection of consumer health and making sure that we never have another crisis like mad cow disease again," Socialist leader Pauline Green said in the statement.
"A censure move now is an ill-judged gesture and politically naive," she said.
An accompanying policy statement said the 214-strong Socialist Group would oppose the censure motion if it is raised when the parliament meets in Strasbourg, France, next week.
Without the backing of the Socialists, the motion stands very little chance of being approved.

Belgian Socialist Euro-MP Jose Happart, the most radical member of a committee of inquiry into the Commission's handling of the BSE crisis, said on Thursday he had enough support to bring a censure motion to a vote.
The Socialist statement referred to Happart indirectly as a "rebel".

A censure motion needs the backing of two-thirds of the votes cast and an absolute majority of 314 votes in the assembly in order to force the resignation of Commission President Jacques Santer and his 19 colleagues.

Last week the 19-member cross-party committee resoundingly rejected a more moderate move by the Green Group under which a censure vote would have been taken only if the Commission failed to take corrective measures by December 1997.
